title: What happened during the British colonial rule in India? - Quora
tags: Impact of Colonial Rule on India

response.answer_text: 1st British reached in India in early 1500s. 2nd Thomas Roe got permit for trade (for East India Co.) in India between 1615–1618. 3rd Battle of Plassey in 1757. 4th Revenue collection rights of Bihar and Bengal 5th Many wars till 1857, 1st war of independence. The power of India passed from East India Co. to British Crown after the war. 6th Birth of Mahatma Gandhi in 1869. 7th Formation of Indian National Congress by AO Hume. 8th Mahatma Gandhi returned to India from South Africa in 1915. 9th First WW-1, Congress supported British in war effort for Independence of India, British betrayed them. 10th India got Independence in 15th August 1947. 11th In the mean while they destroyed Indian industries of Cotton and Sugar and all sources of decent earning in the area directly administered by British. Almost all able bodied men of north India were killed after 1st war of dependence in 1857. Several famines occurred in India especially in Bengal, some of the famine were British made. Enormous wealth of India was looted and shifted to Britain. Indian contribution to worlds GDP fell from about 25% to less than 2% in 1947 and that too after revival of Indian industries due to WW-1 & 2. When Robert Clive returned to England after his tenure in India, he was richest person on the globe, richer than British monarchs. More people died in Bengal due to Churchill made famine of Bengal, more than 3 million than in World wars. From the way, events like cow vigilantism, minority persons being attacked here and there, etc basically there seems to be a different form on unrest that is slowly creeping up in these days. Added to this the political trend whereby one party it looks will be in charge of all India in due course. These do not portend well when read along with the unrest among the youth where we are seeing even post-graduates applying for a waiters job in the canteen in Government here in Tamilnadu. There is a probably all these can add up to internal unrest-which may be a milder form of the earlier freedom struggle and the times of the famous portrayal in the film Dr Zhivago. Of course we have not yet reached the total welfare state where each and every one has all the basic needs taken care of and this is more in other developing countries of S E Asia except Singapore and Malaysia. But the important issue is these are populations in tiny countries to be centrally controlled and kept under check. In India, it will not be so. Unless the problem of unemployment is tackled probably there may emerge a miniature rise of the freedom struggle like the pre-independence stage.
